channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Military Budget to Rise No More Than 8%, Slower Than Usual
item.description: The People’s Liberation Army’s budget will increase by 7 percent to 8 percent this year, a senior official said. Last year it grew 10 percent.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Military delegates arrived for a session of the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: China Plans Modest Rise in Military Spending
item.description: The defense budget will rise by 7 to 8 percent this year, less than the double-digit increases that have been the norm for years, a senior official said Friday.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Police Kill 2 Assailants
item.description: The police in Istanbul killed two women who had hidden inside a building after attacking officers with gunfire and a hand grenade, said Istanbul’s governor, Vasip Sahin.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: Opposition Hones Plan to Remove the President This Year
item.description: The opposition will pursue a constitutional amendment, a recall referendum and a campaign for the resignation of President Nicolás Maduro, an opposition leader said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Mexico City, Comedians Punish Society’s Scofflaws With Humiliation
item.description: Meet the Supercívicos, comedians who embarrass the bad actors of Mexican society with their humor and then put videos of the shaming on social media.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arturo Hernández, left, and Alex Marin y Kall of the Supercívicos, an activist group of comedians whose mission is to embarrass the bad actors of Mexican society with punishing humor.

item.title: North Korea’s Kim Jong-un Tells Military to Have Nuclear Warheads on Standby
item.description: The North Korean leader’s comments were reported a day after the United Nations Security Council approved tougher sanctions aimed at curtailing his country’s nuclear and ballistic-missile programs.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Brazil’s President Rousseff, Facing Impeachment Effort, Is Deluged by More Bad News
item.description: With Brazil’s economy tumbling and her campaign strategist jailed, President Dilma Rousseff now confronts a report that a senator from her party will accuse her in a plea deal.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: World Briefing: U.N. Report Describes Sex Abuse Allegations About Peacekeeping Missions
item.description: There were 69 allegations of sexual exploitation and abuse reported in 10 peacekeeping missions in 2015, the report says as it calls for on-site courts-martial of the accused.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Iran Invites Boeing for Talks, a Stride Toward Business Ties With the U.S.
item.description: The Iranians want to modernize their commercial aircraft fleet, and the invitation could be a precursor to the biggest business arrangement with an American company after decades of estrangement.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Brazil Opens Investigation Into McDonald’s
item.description: The company and its master franchise owner in Latin America are under scrutiny for possible violations of labor, tax and franchise laws.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE STROM and VINOD SREEHARSHA
item.media:description: A demonstration in August of McDonald’s workers in Sao Paulo. Last summer, unions filed a complaint against Arcos Dorados, the company’s master franchiser in Latin America.

item.title: Biblical Nomads Will Return to the Holy Land, Thanks to a Canadian Farm
item.description: A flock of Jacob sheep being raised by a British Columbia couple will be sent to their ancestral homeland in Israel this year.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Jacob sheep, in an image provided by the Friends of the Jacob Sheep in Abbotsford, British Columbia.

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Oscar Pistorius’s Appeal of Conviction Is Rejected
item.description: South Africa’s highest court on Thursday dismissed a final appeal from the former track star to overturn his murder conviction in the 2013 death of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Berta Cáceres, Indigenous Activist, Is Killed in Honduras
item.description: Ms. Cáceres, a winner of the Goldman Environmental Prize, had led a decade-long fight against a proposal to build the Agua Zarca Dam.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and ALBERTO ARCE

item.title: Green Beret Who Hit Afghan Child Rapist Should Be Reinstated, Lawmakers Say
item.description: Sgt. First Class Charles Martland faces discharge after he helped to beat up an Afghan militia commander who kept a boy chained to his bed as a sex slave.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Europe, Reeling From Strain, Tells Economic Migrants: Don’t Bother
item.description: Remarks by Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, signaled Europe’s determined turn away from Germany’s approach to absorbing migrants.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A Syrian family sat on railway tracks in the Greek border village of Idomeni on Thursday during a protest against the slow transit to Macedonia.

item.title: World Briefing: Spain Seizes 20,000 Military Uniforms Bound for ISIS
item.description: The uniforms were part of a shipment declared as “secondhand clothing” and were hidden inside three shipping containers intercepted in the ports of Valencia and Algeciras.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Wheels: VW Scandal Clouds Prospects for Other Diesel Makers at Geneva Motor Show
item.description: Automakers’ plans to use diesel to meet Europe’s tough carbon dioxide limits have been upended by Volkswagen’s admission that it cheated on emissions tests.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: A transparent Volkswagen model on display at the Geneva International Motor Show.

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Remedy for China’s Economic Gloom Has Echoes of Reaganomics
item.description: “Supply-side structural reform” represents an effort to rejuvenate President Xi Jinping’s faltering plans to overhaul the Chinese economy.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Recruiters talked to job seekers at a job fair in Beijing last month. A whole generation of Chinese youth raised in a roaring economy over the past decade are coming of age in a period of material uncertainty as jobs come less easily.

item.title: Maryinka Journal: In Ukraine Towns Ravaged by War, Evangelical Missionaries Find Fertile Ground
item.description: As Ukrainian forces and Russian-backed separatists carry on an almost forgotten fight, several evangelical groups are staging a campaign of their own.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergei N. Kosyak led a service at the Christian Aid Center of the Transfiguration Church in Maryinka, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: South Africa's Highest Court Dismisses Pistorius Appeal
item.description: South Africa's highest court has dismissed Oscar Pistorius' appeal of his murder conviction, a lawyer said Thursday, signaling that the former track star's long legal battle since he killed girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp may be drawing to a close.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
